JUDGES: Isabelle Berro-Lefèvre;Karel Jungwiert;Mirjana Lazarova Trajkovska;Peer Lorenzen;Rait Maruste;Renate Jaeger;Zdravka Kalaydjieva
TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in LOC . He was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE / Main .
In DATE the applicant was convicted of drug trafficking and sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . On DATE the remainder of the sentence was suspended and the applicant released on probation .
As of CARDINAL DATE the police investigated the applicant , suspecting a violation of LAW ( Betäubungsmittelgesetz ) because of chemical purchases by the applicant on a large scale .

On DATE the Gieβen ORG issued a search warrant relating to the applicant ’s GPE house , where he was then living , and ordered telephone surveillance measures . The court based its decisions on the suspicion of a violation of LAW on the ground that the chemicals purchased by the applicant could be used to manufacture narcotics covered by LAW .

In file notes dated DATE , DATE and CARDINAL DATE the investigators observed that it seemed that the applicant wanted to use the chemicals to manufacture new designer drugs not covered by LAW . It was further observed that the new designer drugs might , however , fall within the scope of LAW ( Arzneimittelgesetz ) and its penal provisions .
On DATE the applicant was arrested and subsequently remanded into custody .

On DATE and DATE the house of the applicant ’s parents was searched with the applicant ’s consent on the basis of the search warrant issued on DATE . Chemicals found in the course of the search were seized with the applicant ’s consent .

The applicant was questioned on DATE and accused of a violation of LAW . He remained silent and instead referred to a protective letter ( PERSON ) he was carrying with him at the time of his arrest , in which he claimed that the use of the chemicals was purely for scientific purposes . In this letter he stated inter alia :

“ CARDINAL ) Medicinal Products of the Medicines Act are o n l y those substances and preparations which are authorised as medicinal products or registered or are exempted from the need for authorisation or registration by ordinance ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) Medicines Act ) ... ”

On DATE , after having heard the applicant , the ORG issued an arrest warrant . The applicant remained in pre - trial custody until DATE , when the enforcement of the arrest warrant was suspended . On DATE the arrest warrant was rescinded .
The pre - trial investigations were closed on DATE .
On DATE the applicant was charged with CARDINAL violations of LAW and CARDINAL violations of LAW .
On DATE the indictment was served on the applicant ’s defence lawyer .
On DATE the defence lawyer requested the ORG not to open the main proceedings .
On DATE the ORG declined to open the main proceedings .
On DATE the prosecution submitted grounds for its appeal against the decision of DATE to ORG .
On DATE and DATE respectively the applicant himself and his defence lawyer filed submissions .
On DATE ORG directed the Gieβen Regional Court to open the main proceedings with regard to the alleged violations of LAW .

On DATE the prosecution submitted a revised indictment , charging the applicant with the manufacture of medicinal products without authorisation in CARDINAL cases , in CARDINAL case in conjunction with placing on the market ( Inverkehrbringen ) unsafe medicinal products .

On DATE the ORG fixed the date of the trial for DATE , after the defence lawyer had indicated that he was tied up with business on ORG regular trial days from DATE , and since another case had already been scheduled for DATE .

The trial on DATE ended with the acquittal of the applicant . The ORG argued that the manufactured substance , Methyl - Methaqualon , did not constitute a medicinal product as defined in section CARDINAL § CARDINAL no . CARDINAL of LAW . With regard to the other substance , ORG , ORG ( “ MBDB ” ) , the court reasoned that it could not be ruled out that it only constituted an intermediate ( NORP ) which did not fall within the scope of LAW .
The prosecution appealed the judgment and on DATE submitted grounds for its appeal on points of law .
On DATE ORG held a hearing .

On DATE ORG set aside the judgment of ORG . ORG argued that ORG had applied an incorrect definition of “ medicinal product ” ; ORG did in fact constitute a medicinal product as defined in section CARDINAL § CARDINAL no . CARDINAL of LAW . If , as in the case at hand , the purpose of the substance could not be derived from objective criteria , consumer expectation or scientific assessment , the point of reference had to be the purpose pursued by the manufacturer , which in this case was the applicant ’s intention to develop substances with the same or similar effects as narcotic substances without falling within the scope of LAW as described in his protective letter . With regard to the substance MBDB ORG argued that the development of an intermediate product could suffice for the alleged offence under LAW .
In DATE the files were referred back to the Gieβen ORG .
On DATE the trial was listed for DATE and DATE .
After the defence lawyer had indicated that he would not be able to attend the trial on DATE the dates were changed to CARDINAL DATE and DATE .

During the trial on DATE the defence lawyer , referring to the recent case - law of ORG , objected to the use of the evidence found during the search of the applicant ’s GPE house since the search warrant had been DATE at the time of its execution ( see relevant domestic law and practice below ) .
On DATE the trial ended with the sentencing of the applicant to a cumulative prison sentence ( Gesamtfreiheitsstrafe ) of DATE suspended on probation .

The applicant gave notice of his intention to appeal on points of law and submitted his statement of the grounds of appeal on DATE . He raised the issue of the length of the proceedings and challenged the use of the evidence found during the search of his GPE house .
On DATE the prosecution filed a counterstatement ( ORG ) .

On DATE the attorney general ( ORG ) filed a motion to dismiss the appeal with regard to the verdict ( Schuldspruch ) but , because of the length of the proceedings , to set aside the sentence ( Strafausspruch ) and remit the case in this respect .
On DATE the applicant himself submitted another statement .
On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal on points of law with regard to the verdict , set aside the sentence and remitted the case to ORG for sentencing .

On DATE , following a trial hearing , the ORG fixed CARDINAL separate sentences of CARDINAL months’ and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment and imposed a cumulative suspended prison sentence of DATE for the manufacture of medicinal products without authorisation in CARDINAL cases and a fine of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL as a condition of probation ( PERSON ) . In its reasoning regarding the sentence ( PERSON ) ORG expressly took into consideration the length of the proceedings .

On DATE the applicant himself and on DATE his defence lawyer appealed on points of law against this judgment , arguing that the proceedings should be discontinued because of the excessive length of the proceedings violating LAW .
On DATE the attorney general filed a motion to dismiss the appeal .
On DATE the applicant filed a reply .

On DATE ORG set aside the sentence and once again remitted the case to ORG . ORG argued that the judgment did not distinguish between the penalty which would have been adequate without considering the length of the proceedings and the sentence actually imposed , which had been reduced in view of the length of the proceedings .

At DATE the files were referred back to ORG . Because the schedule of responsibilities ( Geschäftsverteilungsplan ) of ORG did not provide for a third remittal , another criminal division ( Strafkammer ) was established on DATE .
On DATE the main lay judges ( PERSON ) for the newly established criminal division were drawn by lot .
On DATE a trial date was set for DATE .
On DATE the defence lawyer complained about the composition of the court , arguing that the judges should have been drawn by lot .
On DATE ORG dismissed the complaint .

On DATE ORG imposed a cumulative suspended sentence of DATE for the manufacture of medicinal products without authorisation in CARDINAL cases and a fine of ORG CARDINAL,CARDINAL as a condition of probation . In its reasoning regarding the sentence ORG expressly acknowledged a violation of LAW and in view of this reduced the adequate separate sentences of CARDINAL and CARDINAL months’ imprisonment by CARDINAL to CARDINAL QUANTITY months’ and the adequate cumulative sentence of DATE imprisonment to CARDINAL months’ imprisonment .
On DATE the written judgment was put on file ; on CARDINAL DATE it was served on the defence lawyer .
On DATE the defence lawyer submitted grounds of appeal on points of law . He again raised the issue of the length of the proceedings .
On DATE the prosecution filed a counterstatement .
On DATE the applicant filed an appeal on points of law .
Because of a signature mistake new executed copies of the judgment were issued on DATE and served on the defence lawyer on DATE .
On DATE the applicant submitted further reasons for the appeal on points of law .
On DATE the attorney general filed a motion to dismiss the appeal .
On DATE ORG dismissed the appeal without giving reasons .

On DATE the applicant lodged a first constitutional complaint with ORG against the judgment of ORG of DATE , the judgment of the Gieβen Regional Court of DATE and the decision of ORG of DATE . In his constitutional complaint the applicant challenged the alleged lack of legal certainty of the penal provisions of LAW in connection with the definition of “ medicinal product ” , the search of his GPE house on the basis of an DATE search warrant and the subsequent use of the evidence obtained in the course of this search , and the length of the then still pending proceedings .

On DATE the applicant lodged a second constitutional complaint against the judgment of ORG of DATE and the judgment of the Gieβen Regional Court of DATE , again raising the issue of the length of the proceedings .

On DATE the applicant lodged a final constitutional complaint against the judgment of the Gieβen Regional Court of DATE and the decision of ORG of DATE , arguing that the reduction of the sentence was not sufficient compensation for the excessive length of the proceedings .

On DATE ORG refused to admit the applicant ’s CARDINAL constitutional complaints for examination on the ground that they were ill - founded ( file no . CARDINAL BvR CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) . ORG denied a lack of legal certainty with regard to the penal provisions of LAW . ORG expressly acknowledged a violation of LAW ( inviolability of the home ) by the execution of the search warrant DATE after its issue . However , the court argued that the judgment had not been based on this violation because in the case at hand the violation of LAW did not entail the exclusion of the evidence obtained . The exclusion of evidence could only be considered if the procedural defects were severe , intentional or arbitrary . In the case at hand there was no intentional violation since it was DATE after the search that ORG had established a “ date of expiry ” for search warrants . ORG further argued that the overall length of the proceedings , while too long , was no reason for a discontinuation of the proceedings as submitted by the applicant . It rather had to be left to the lower courts to remedy an excessive length of the proceedings by reducing the sentence .
On DATE ORG decision was served on the applicant ’s lawyer .
LAW ) , dealing with the inviolability of the home , prescribes in its paragraph CARDINAL that a search of LOC may - in principle - only be ordered by a judge .

In its decision of CARDINAL DATE ( file no . CARDINAL BvR CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) ORG held that this requirement of a judicial order ( NORP ) implied that a search warrant must be executed within DATE of its issue . After DATE the judicial search warrant loses its vindicatory power and the search then constitutes a violation of LAW .
Section CARDINAL
“ The term ‘ medicinal product’
( CARDINAL ) Medicinal products are substances and preparations made from substances which , by application on or in the human or animal body , are intended ( ... )
CARDINAL . to influence either the nature , the state or the functions of the body or mental health conditions . ( ... )

( CARDINAL ) As long as a product is authorised or registered as a medicinal product pursuant to the present Act , or is exempted from the need for authorisation or registration by ordinance , such product shall be considered a medicinal product . A product shall not be considered a medicinal product if its authorisation or registration has been rejected by the competent ORG , on the ground that it is not a medicinal product . ”
Section CARDINAL
“ Prohibition of unsafe medicinal products
( CARDINAL ) The placing on the market of unsafe medicinal products shall be prohibited .

( CARDINAL ) Medicinal products shall be considered unsafe if , according to the current level of scientific knowledge , there is reason to suspect that , when used in accordance with their intended purpose , they have harmful effects which exceed the limits considered tolerable in the light of current medical knowledge . ”
Section CARDINAL
“ Manufacturing authorisation

( CARDINAL ) Any person wishing to manufacture medicinal products within the meaning of section CARDINAL sub - section CARDINAL or sub - section CARDINAL No . CARDINAL ... on a commercial or professional basis for the purpose of dispensing to others , shall require an authorisation by the competent authority . ... Distribution to others , in the meaning of the first sentence , shall exist if the person manufacturing the medicinal product is not the same as the person using it . ... ”
Section CARDINAL
“ GPE provisions
( CARDINAL ) Any person who

CARDINAL . contrary to LAW , markets medicinal products suspected on reasonable grounds of being capable of causing harmful effects , ... shall be liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding DATE or to a fine . ”
Section CARDINAL
“ Penal Provisions
Any person who ...
CARDINAL . in breach of LAW sub - section CARDINAL , manufactures medicinal products within the meaning of LAW sub - section CARDINAL ... without authorisation , ... ,
shall be liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding one year or to a fine . ”
